abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Sector
            Development (SSD) Project for Romania were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            greater emphasis should have been placed on training, SSD
            allocated 1700 staff days to training, a large allocation,
            but even more training was needed. Principally, additional
            training will have facilitated utilization by end-users of
            Information Technology (IT) systems installed at their
            level, and thereby enhanced efficiency of using the systems,
            and reduced errors inputted. It would also have drastically
            reduced the interval that end-users required to become
            familiar with system procedures and thus use them more
            efficiently, reducing pension system costs. The role of
            local agencies in the delivery of social services is
            critical, In providing support for local Ministry of Labor
            and Social Solidarity (MMSS) staff and for the award of 70
            sub-project grants, SSD was able to strengthen the technical
            ability to deliver services to those in great need, but also
            to: increase the breadth and quality of outreach; increase
            the liaison between MMSS with local Non-Governmental
            Organizations (NGOs) and other organizations of all types;
            make available 'demonstrators' of key medical
            equipment that patients needed for support. This increased
            the familiarity and knowledge of this equipment, crucial for
            many disabled patients, for a broader range of individuals.
            Finally, the national ability to recognize disabilities, and
            how they could be dealt with in the best way, was enhanced.

10952079.trustfund: TF025357-PHRD-CHILD WELFARE PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF026138-PHRD-SOCIAL SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Social Sector Development Project
            : project restructuring and amendment of Loan Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This amendment to the Loan Agreement
            reflects the proposed restructuring of the Social Sector
            Development Project, combined with an extension of the
            closing date by June 30, 2007. The key elements of this
            restructuring are: 1)  Reduction in the allocation of loan
            proceeds, reflecting the ability of the unemployment fund to
            finance these services to a major extent. 2) Increase in the
            allocation of loan proceeds to the Pension Administration
            sub-component, to enable the completion of the computerized
            management information system. 3) Reduction in the
            allocation of loan proceeds to the Pension Supervision
            Commission (PSC) sub-component, reflecting the resulting
            efficiency gains. 4) Loan proceeds allocation to various
            subcomponents, reflecting either, the fact that anticipated
            bilateral grant finance for this activity, did not
            materialize, or recognition of higher cost-effectiveness,
            both in information technology, or systems design.

19432614.trustfund: TF025357-PHRD-CHILD WELFARE PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF026138-PHRD-SOCIAL SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Sector Development (SSD)
            Project aims to contribute towards increased economic growth
            and poverty reduction in Romania. The project consists of
            four components. 1) The first component will strengthen the
            policy development, monitoring, and evaluation capacity of
            the government on poverty reduction and the core Ministry of
            Labor and Social Solidarity (MMSS) in social protection.
            This will be achieved through technical assistance and staff
            training, policy specific studies and program outcome
            evaluations, and the installation of a Central Management
            Information System within the MMSS. 2) The social insurance
            system reform component includes pension administration,
            development of the Pension Supervision Commission, and
            Occupational Hazards Insurance. 3) The labor market
            adjustment component, including the labor reemployment
            program and micro-credit subcomponents, will support
            adjustment of labor policy and programs to support
            adjustment of labor policy and programs to enhance economic
            reform. 4) The social assistance strengthening component
            will support the implementation of the new institutional
            framework for social assistance under the new Law on Social
            Assistance. This component includes three subcomponents:
            institution building based on pilot social assistance
            offices at the judets level; personnel development; and communications.
